author: Ketan Joshi

Um, basically no. 

The atmosphere and ocean equilibrate rapidly. In the large, any added vapour is balanced by suppressing evaporation.

The biggest exception is ‚Äúcorn sweat‚Äù. Large hot irrigated areas  can exacerbate humidity and greenhouse forcing locally. But the global effect is very small.

author: Dr Tom Harris
text: The albedo reduction is partly due to ice loss, but mostly due to a reduction in cloud cover and changes in the make-up of clouds, especially low level clouds in a warming atmosphere. This feedback response amplifies the effect of the greenhouse warming (=138ppm extra CO2).
Nothing absurd about a fact you could look up any time. The first experimental demonstration of the greenhouse effect was in 1859.

text:
In 2015, climate scientists warned that in order to prevent the planet from extreme weather phenomena - like those once in a 100 years events - we have to stay below 1.5¬∞C warming. 
We've passed that earlier this year and heading towards 2¬∞C. 
What's the difference?
IT'S 10 TIMES WORSE.

Please comment on your plans relative to rapidly accelerating climate change fuelled extreme weather events, and your short, medium, long term plans for lessening these impacts.
Please describe impacts of your plan.

1. Changing stress on faults
Melting Glaciers and Ice Sheets: The immense weight of glaciers and ice sheets exerts pressure on the Earth's crust beneath them. As these masses melt due to climate change, the crust experiences a release of pressure, a process known as isostatic rebound.

text:
My main concerns about AI are:

1. It steals.

Each of these COULD be addressed via proper regulation, but it‚Äôs not, and it won‚Äôt be‚Äînot in the USA anyway.

author: Izzy Seabiscuit
text:
Excellent choice of examples!

CA YIMBY has not lobbied "against CEQA". Rather, it has recognized that CEQA has been weaponized to stop infill and dense housing, which is pretty unambiguously good for the environment writ-large. AB130, which CAYIMBY supported, is pro-environmental regulation.

author: üá∫üá∏üá≤üáΩ The Babe with the Power
text:
This was always a reason to not use them. Besides the whole wage theft and environmental impact things.

They exist to shirk regulation.

Does regulation stop males? No. Humanity keeps raising them and allowing them to get away with it.

But this relatively unregulated corporation isn't helping.

Thank you. Reading now! High level thoughts: 1) Crypto ABSOLUTELY needs regulation- agree. 2) The only argument against other tech companies I saw was re: AI server farms. We should definitely continue to (try!) and elect climate-aware politicians to help control the environmental effects.

author: Humblemud
text: The problem with AI, other than the environmental issues which are huge, is there is basically no regulation or legislation around it. There is no guidance about how to utilize AI properly. It's a wild west environment

author: Spinoza at a bad dinner party.
text:
Environmental regulations are indeed a type of regulation that the heritage foundation has attacked (CEQA).

Speculators do indeed sit on empty units - this is a common strategy. RE as a store of wealth is commonplace as well. The problem is that this artificially inflates housing prices up.

It's not enough to influence congressional seats, but I've been wondering about the downstream effects of his overall attacks on majority-minority urban centers, which normally may swing a state blue. Removing entitlement programs, environmental regulation, infrastructure spending, etc.

author: Benedikt Bender

üí°To sum upüí°

Research so far has overlooked the role of subsidies in ensuring broad-based support for eco-social policy from both unions & employer associations. 

We show that green subsidies tend to reduce opposition, & increase support for eco-social policy.

author: Benedikt Bender
text:
Can the IRA‚Äôs green subsidies ensure its political survival under Trump? 

We believe that green subsidies may very well prove resilient in the long run, thanks to business, labor, Democratic, & moderate Republican support.

author: Benedikt Bender
text: USA: we also show support for green subsidies among American business organizations & trade unions. Business groups see innovation & green tech gains; unions support them as subsidies are tied to pro-labor standards (positive-sum effect).

author: Benedikt Bender
text: üö® Important for our other argument is that the unions support green subsidies because they are only paid to companies in which collective agreements or other forms of union representation are in place (positive-sum).

author: Benedikt Bender
text:
In Germany: as we had expected green subsidies play an important role in increasing the support of eco-social policy reforms. 

All of the most representative business associations & trade unions agree that green subsidies should be used to manage the transformation process.

author: Benedikt Bender
text: We argue that green subsidies facilitate support for eco-social policies by transforming a zero-sum game of risks, costs, & distributional conflict into a mutually beneficial, positive sum game of benefits for both unions & businesses.

author: Dave-Inder Comar
text:
The climate governance regime enshrined by the Paris Agreement assumes linear climate impacts. 

But now our world faces non-linear impacts, particularly climate tipping points.

Policymakers must understand and address non-linearity. 

Put simply¬†‚Äî"what is the plan for non-linear climate impacts?"

text: Climate policy rests entirely on the promise of models. If models prove inadequate, the whole governance apparatus collapses. author: JAMTAM
text: The assumption for IPCC assessment is that climate science is capable to provide a concrete foundation towards actionable governance goals. It is obvious that stacking ensembles on ensembles and sampling them can lead to nothing more than a model fog, but fogs do not provide solid foundations.
